data.title: Support underscore templates in "html.format.enable"

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
**Versions**

- VSCode Version: Version 1.10.0-insider (1.10.0-insider)
- OS Version: Mac OS X 10.12.3 

**Steps to Reproduce**

1. Set `"html.format.enable"` to `true`.
2. Open the following `index.html` and format the file:

```html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
  <meta charset="utf-8">
  <% console.log('hello') %>
  <title>Login</title>
</head>
<body>
  <%
    // copy configs
    require('copy-loader!./foo.js');
  %>
  <script src="foo.js"></script>
</body>
</html>
```

**What did I expect?**

No changes.

**What was the actual result?**

```html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
  <meta charset="utf-8">
  <% console.log('hello') %>
    <title>Login</title>
</head>
<body>
  <%
    // copy configs
    require('copy-loader!./foo.js');
  %>
    <script src="foo.js"></script>
</body>
</html>
```

It looks like every tag after `<% %>` is indented by two spaces.

**Why should this be changed?**

Underscore templates within HTML are a common feature in solutions like [html-webpack-plugin](https://github.com/jantimon/html-webpack-plugin).

data.title: Why is Mac terminal complaining “-bash: export: `PATH;': not a valid identifier”
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.0
- OS Version: 10.12.3

This may not be VS Code, that's just a hunch. On my Mac when I start a terminal it first reports the error

`-bash: export: 'PATH;': not a valid identifier`

This appears to stem from the last line of my `~/.bash_profile` file:

`export VISUAL=vscodeeval $(/usr/libexec/path_helper -s)`

since commenting out the line fixes the issue. Is that line something added by VS Code when it installs?

(Stack Exchange question [here](http://apple.stackexchange.com/q/272194/142445).)

data.title: DEL key doesn't work when renaming a file
data.body:

- OS Version: Windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Select a file in the explorer menu
2. Start rename a file
3. Try to delete the next character via the `DEL` key --> Nothing happens.

It works in the current stable release.

data.title: Proposal: More flexible task definition

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Version 1.9 brought long-awaited (at least by me) multiple commands for task definition, but the way tasks are defined is still rigid, there are a lot of attributes that can only be defined in the root of task.json.

I propose a simple system with inheritance and overriding:  
```
rootTaskgroup
      |-->task0
      |-->task1
      |-->taskgroup0
             |-->task00
             |-->task01
             |-->taskgroup00
                    |-->task000
```

`rootTaskgroup`  has every attribute defined by default or by specification.  
`taskgroup` inherits all attributes of the  parent and can override any attribute.
`task` inherits all attributes of the parent and can override any.  
___Only exception to the rule is task's name, which must be defined for each task separately.___

In the end, when parsing configuration file you obtain a list of tasks.
_update: made the model more uniform_

data.title: Test: column breakpoints
data.body:
- [x] win @chrmarti 
- [x] os x @rebornix
- [x] linux @aeschli 

Complexity: 4
Refs: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/14784

We now support setting breakpoints on a column. In order for column breakpoints to be respected the debug adapter extension has to support them - at the moment `node` debugger is supporting column breakpoints.
Have a worskpace that you can debug and verify:
* You can add column breakpoints via comand palette and via context menu during a debug session
* Breakpoint location is updated by the debug adapter if needed
* Execution is stopped on the column breakpoint
* Column breakpoints are nicely decorated in the editor
* Disable some column breakpoints and add some conditions to column brekapoints - make sure this is nicely decorated in the editor and respected by the execution

|---|---|---|

|Ruby|rebornix|0.10.4|
|markdown-all-in-one|yzhang|0.2.0|

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Include `"window.menuBarVisibility": "hidden"` in `settings.json`
2. Observe menubar hides after saving settings
3. Close application
4. Re-open
5. **Observe menubar shows again after startup, even with the setting in-tact**

Additional Notes:
- Menubar toggle stops working
- To make the menubar invisible again, I have to go to settings, yank the setting, save `settings.json`, re-add the setting, and then save again

data.title: The glob pattern given to createFileSystemWatcher is matched against the full fs path
data.body:
Like most tools that ask for user input in the form of the glob, it should be matched against the relative path to a reference, in this case the workspace.

Example:

- I have a `log` file in my `/Users/joao/what` workspace .
- `workspace.createFileSystemWatcher('log')` doesn't give me any events
- `workspace.createFileSystemWatcher('**/log')` does, because the glob is matched against `/Users/joao/what/log`.

I find that very confusing especially given that `createFileSystemWatcher` is called upon a `workspace` object.

data.title: 4-byte UTF8 code point reported as 2 chars in textDocument/didChange
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9
- OS Version: All.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Add a 4-byte UTF8 code point (e.g. 𐍈 or 𠜎 ) to a new file (e.g. C++).
2. Delete it and put a breakpoint in an extension that handles the textDocument/didChange protocol (e.g. the C++ extension).

Bug: The result from VS Code is that TextDocumentContentChangeEvent rangeLength is 2, so our extension sees that the 1st character is correctly 4 bytes, but then it tries to process a non-existent 2nd character (crashing the process or corrupting data). Other APIs that pass the unexpected character position may also break functionality.

It seems like VS Code should make available the real character length of an edit so extensions can behavior correctly. VS Code reports the 4-byte code point as taking up 2 columns, which is consistent with the rangeLength of 2.

As a workaround, we will assume that all 4-byte code points take up 2 characters and all other code points take up 1 character. Does that seem like a good workaround? I don't know for sure which UTF8 code points count as 2 or more characters.
